definition.p: Let d:X^2\to[0,\infty) be a function satisfying the following for all x,y,z\in X.

ol.li: d(x,y)=0 if and only if x=y.

definition.p: Then d is said to be a metric on the set X, and B_r(x)=\setBuilder{y\in X}{d(x,y)\lt r} is said to be a metric ball around x.

example.title: Examples of metrics
example.p: Verify that each of the following is a metric.

ol.li: d(x,y)=1 for all distinct x,y\in X, and d(x,x)=0

definition.p: The topology generated by the basis given in is called the topology generated by the metric.
A given topology is said to be metrizable if there exists some metric that generates it. Two metrics are said to be topologically equivalent if they generate the same topology.

theorem.p: Two bases \mc B_0,\mc B_1 generate the same topology if and only if for all x\in B_0\in\mc B_0 there exists B_1\in\mc B_1 such that x\in B_1\subseteq B_0, and for all x\in B_1\in\mc B_1 there exists B_0\in\mc B_0 such that x\in B_0\subseteq B_1.

Let B_{0,r}(x),B_{1,r}(x) be the metric balls around x given by two metrics d_0,d_1 respectively. Then d_0,d_1 are topologically equivalent if and only if for all x\in X and \epsilon\gt 0, there exists \delta\gt 0 such that B_{0,\delta}(x)\subseteq B_{1,\epsilon} and B_{1,\delta}(x)\subseteq B_{0,\epsilon}(x).
The following metrics on \mb R^n are topologically equivalent.

li.m: d(\vec x,\vec y)=\sqrt{\sum_{0\leq i\lt n}(\vec y(i)-\vec x(i))^2}
d(\vec x,\vec y)=\sum_{0\leq i\lt n}|\vec y(i)-\vec x(i)|
d(\vec x,\vec y)=\max\setBuilder{|\vec y(i)-\vec x(i)|}{0\leq i\lt n}

definition.p: The topology generated by the metrics given in is called the Euclidean topology on \mb R^n.
A local basis at a point x is a collection of open sets \mc B_x such that for every neighborhood U of x, there exists B\in\mc B_x such that x\in B_x\subseteq U.
A space is said to be first-countable if there exists a countable local basis at every point of the space.
A space is said to be second-countable if there exists a countable basis for the space.
A space is said to be separable if there exists a countable dense subset of the space.

theorem.p: Let X be metrizable. Then X is second-countable if and only if it is separable.

proposition.p: Every Euclidean space is separable and second-countable.

theorem.p: For \vec x,\vec y\in\mb R^2, let d(\vec x,\vec y)=1 if \vec x(1)\not=\vec y(1), and d(\vec x,\vec y)=|\vec y(0)-\vec x(0)| otherwise. Then d is a metric generating a non-separable, non-discrete topology on \mb R^2.
The subspace \setBuilder{\vec x}{\vec{x}(1)\in\setList{0,1}} of the space defined in is homeomorphic to the subspace (0,1)\cup(2,3) of the Euclidean line.

definition.p: A point x is called a sequential limit point of a set A iff there exists a countable subset B\subseteq A\setminus\setList{x} such that every neighborhood of x contains all but finitely many points of B.

proposition.p: Every sequential limit point of a set is a limit point of that set.

theorem.p: Let X be first-countable. Then x is a limit point of a set if and only if x is a sequental limit point of that set.

definition.p: A complete metric is a metric such that every Cauchy sequence has a sequential limit point.
A topology that can be generated by a complete metric is said to be completely metrizable.

proposition.p: Every Euclidean space is completely metrizable.
Let d:X\to[0,\infty) be a metric and Y\subseteq X. Then d restricted to Y generates the subspace topology on Y. (Therefore, every subspace of a metrizable space is metrizable.)

theorem.p: The subspace (0,1) of the Euclidean line is completely metrizable, but not by the topology inherited from \mb R.
The subspace \mb Q of the Euclidean line is metrizable, but not completely metrizable.
The subspace \mb R\setminus\mb Q of the Euclidean line is completely metrizable, but not by the topology inherited from \mb R.
Metrizable and completely metrizable are topological properties. That is, if X and Y are homeomorphic, then X is (completely) metrizable if and only if Y is too.
